<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/supreme-court-ruling-athlete-compensation-deals-blow-ncaa?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Supreme Court Sits in the Student Section
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/supreme-court-ruling-athlete-compensation-deals-blow-ncaa?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="An illustration of a bronze Heisman trophy in front of a turquoise background. The statue shows a football player running with a ball. In his outstretched hand, he is holding up a rolled-up diploma with a ribbon." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NTEzL2hlaXNtYW5fdHJvcGh5X2lsbHVzdHJhdGlvbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">College athletes scored another big W in their looooong quest to get paid for their work on the field.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the US Supreme Court <a href="https://apnews.com/article/ncaa-supreme-court-alston-college-athlete-benefits-5be12caeaf014da7d71baf0bb60646fe?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ruled unanimously</a> that the NCAA cannot stop colleges from compensating student athletes, as long as that compensation is tied to education.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So you won't see your favorite running back receiving a salary (yet). But athletes can now receive monetary benefits like tutoring, study abroad, academic awards, and more.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The Xs and Os</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Writing the court's decision, Justice Neil Gorsuch explained that the NCAA, the 115-year-old organization that governs college athletics, is <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/supreme-court-rejects-ncaas-tight-limits-on-athlete-benefits-compensation-11624285407?mod=hp_lead_pos1" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not exempt</a> from antitrust laws put in place to promote fair competition. But it was Justice Kavanaugh who really <a href="https://twitter.com/SportsLawGuy/status/1406986290009157634?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">skewered</a> the NCAA with the passion of an aggrieved LSU baseball fan. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“The bottom line is that the NCAA and its member colleges are suppressing the pay of student athletes who collectively generate </span><span><em>billions </em></span><span>of dollars in revenues for colleges every year.”</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“But the student athletes who generate the revenues, many of whom are African American and from lower-income backgrounds, end up with little or nothing.” </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Interesting fact: </strong>College coaches were the <a href="http://www.espn.com/espn/feature/story?id=28261213&_slug_=dabo-swinney-ed-orgeron-highest-paid-state-employees&redirected=true" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">highest-paid public employee</a> in 40 states in 2019.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For its part, the NCAA claims that compensating student athletes would undermine the “amateur” flavor of college sports, damaging fans' enjoyment of the product.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But that argument is increasingly sounding tone-deaf</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And lawmakers are chipping away at the NCAA's stranglehold. At least seven states have passed bills allowing college athletes to make money from their names, images, and likenesses that go into effect next week. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>this trickle of bad news for the NCAA could turn into a flood. If more justices adopt Kavanaugh's aggressive stance, “It could only be a matter of time before all of the NCAA's restrictions on compensation are struck down as antitrust violations,” Tulane sports law administrator Gabe Feldman <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/21/us/supreme-court-ncaa-student-athletes.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told the NYT</a>.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORK
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/wework-posts-best-2month-sales-streak-since-2019?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Nature Is Healing and Employees Are WeWorking
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like Jon Snow, WeWork's making the most of its second chance. From April to May, the company <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/wework-posts-best-sales-since-100000564.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sold more desks</a> than it had cancellations, making it WeWork's best stretch for sales since September 2019, Bloomberg reported.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Although its occupancy rate has improved to 53%, that's still well below its former peak of ~70%.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Give WeWork some credit</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After shelving its IPO plans in 2019, it went from most-anticipated stock to laughing stock. But then WeWork implemented tough-but-necessary changes under the supervision of major investor SoftBank. It parted ways with CEO Adam Neumann and dramatically cut expenses, including through thousands of layoffs.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While the pandemic was initially a gut punch, it also offered the company <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/wework-imploded-2019-pandemic-brought-it-back-life-n1267957?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a shot at reinvention</a>.<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>More offices are looking for hybrid or remote-friendly setups, and WeWork is once again poised to scratch the labor market's newest itch. The company is already offering more flexible memberships with on-demand booking and access to multiple locations.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>WeWork is tracking for $1.9 billion in revenue and aims to go public this year exactly how you'd expect: a $9 billion SPAC deal with BowX Acquisition Corp.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/spielbergs-amblin-partners-agrees-make-movies-netflix?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Catch Netflix If You Can
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/spielbergs-amblin-partners-agrees-make-movies-netflix?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Leonardo DiCaprio clapping in Catch Me If You Can" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=369 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/CogAtAK2r5M1W/giphy.gif">

<img class="story-header-image" alt="Leonardo DiCaprio clapping in Catch Me If You Can" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/CogAtAK2r5M1W/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Steven Spielberg's production company, Amblin Partners, is speeding toward the future of entertainment with a <a href="https://variety.com/2021/film/news/steven-spielberg-netflix-amblin-deal-1235001513/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new Netflix deal</a>. The company has agreed to produce two or more movies a year for the streamer, some of which could be directed by Spielberg himself.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The deal won't affect Amblin's current partnership with Universal, to which it supplies three-to-five movies a year.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This is a sign of <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/netflix-strikes-deal-with-filmmaker-steven-spielberg-11624293296?mod=e2tw" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">changing times</a> for Hollywood: In a 2018 interview, Spielberg said this about streaming: “You certainly, if it's a good show, deserve an Emmy, but not an Oscar.” This year, Netflix received 36 Oscar nominations.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">And Netflix wants more</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company plans to release 70 movies in 2021—which may seem overly ambitious, but streaming companies are in a sprint to stockpile the most, and best, content. Just last month, Amazon acquired MGM, and with it the historic studio's entire back catalog, including all the <em>James Bond</em>,<em> Legally Blonde</em>, and <em>Rocky</em> movies.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Striking a deal with Spielberg is a flex for Netflix; he has more Oscars under his belt than any other living filmmaker.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>

<img alt="A photo of the front of a Costco store" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MTg4L2Nvc3Rjby5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Costco</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>The number of Costco memberships is <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-06-21/millennial-home-buyers-costco-is-calling-you?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">now higher</a> than the number of US households that pay for cable TV, according to Bloomberg. The renewal rate was 91% last year, when Costco's stock jumped 33%.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>"My life isn't worth a dead-end job." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">23-year-old Aislinn Potts of Tennessee told the Washington Post why she <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/06/21/retail-workers-quitting-jobs/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">left her $11/hr job</a> at a national pet chain retailer to pursue her interests writing and making art. She's not alone: More people quit the retail industry in April (~649,000) than any other month on record. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Covid proved the CDC was broken. Can it be fixed? (<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/16/magazine/cdc-covid-response.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NYT Magazine</a>)</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD & BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/wingstop-launches-chicken-thigh-brand-thighstop?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Thighstop, Full Stop
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/wingstop-launches-chicken-thigh-brand-thighstop?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A press image from Wingstop's Thighstop. A basket of wings is pictured in front of a dark green background. The words " where flavor gets its thighs" are written above." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NTE0L3RoaWdoc3RvcC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Thighstop</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, restaurant chain Wingstop <a href="https://www.restaurantdive.com/news/wingstop-debuts-virtual-brand-focused-on-chicken-thighs/601917/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">launched</a> a new virtual brand, Thighstop, selling crunchy chicken thighs. Alas, Wingstop's embrace of the mighty thigh has not come about because consumers finally realized they've been overpaying for the worst cut of chicken.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It's because wings are in short supply. </strong>They've been a popular takeout dish during the pandemic, but now that strong demand is crashing up against a nationwide chicken shortage, prices are flying. Wingstop's wholesale prices <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/21/business/chicken-thighs-wingstop/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">have risen</a> from as little as 98 cents last year to over $3 now, according to the company's CEO.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Thighstop won't just be a departure from Wingstop's namesake business. The company will use its existing physical restaurants to prepare the meals, but the menu will be available online only as Wingstop tries to keep its "digital momentum" from the pandemic going. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Digital sales now account for 65% of Wingstop's business and topped $1 billion last year. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Changing demographics have boosted dark meat's popularity in recent years. Thighstop may be as mainstream as it gets.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before you dig into today's trivia, first play our <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/21/brew-mini-sled-dogs?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brew Mini crossword puzzle</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Okay, this one's a full-brain workout: We'll give you the name of the chapters to a particular Wikipedia entry, and you have to name the entry. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Chapter titles: </strong>Plato's dialogues, Interpretations, Location hypotheses, Literary interpretations, Artistic representations</p>

#1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebest day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in more than three months, with energy and industrials setting the pace. Bitcoin prices continue to feel the heat from China's crackdown on crypto mining.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eEconomy:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Jerome Powell testifies before Congress today. In his prepared remarks, the Fed chair \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-21/powell-repeats-inflation-pressures-should-subside-toward-goal?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill echo\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e last week’s press conference where he said the central bank expects inflation to fall back closer to its longer-term 2% target.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! The statue shows a football player running with a ball. In his outstretched hand, he is holding up a rolled-up diploma with a ribbon.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NTEzL2hlaXNtYW5fdHJvcGh5X2lsbHVzdHJhdGlvbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCollege athletes scored another big W in their looooong quest to get paid for their work on the field.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the US Supreme Court \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/ncaa-supreme-court-alston-college-athlete-benefits-5be12caeaf014da7d71baf0bb60646fe?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eruled unanimously\u003c/a\u003e that the NCAA cannot stop colleges from compensating student athletes, as long as that compensation is tied to education.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo you won't see your favorite running back receiving a salary (yet). But athletes can now receive monetary benefits like tutoring, study abroad, academic awards, and more.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe Xs and Os\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWriting the court's decision, Justice Neil Gorsuch explained that the NCAA, the 115-year-old organization that governs college athletics, is \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/supreme-court-rejects-ncaas-tight-limits-on-athlete-benefits-compensation-11624285407?mod=hp_lead_pos1\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enot exempt\u003c/a\u003e from antitrust laws put in place to promote fair competition. But it was Justice Kavanaugh who really \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SportsLawGuy/status/1406986290009157634?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eskewered\u003c/a\u003e the NCAA with the passion of an aggrieved LSU baseball fan. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e“The bottom line is that the NCAA and its member colleges are suppressing the pay of student athletes who collectively generate \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003ebillions \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eof dollars in revenues for colleges every year.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“But the student athletes who generate the revenues, many of whom are African American and from lower-income backgrounds, end up with little or nothing.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eInteresting fact: \u003c/strong\u003eCollege coaches were the \u003ca href=\"http://www.espn.com/espn/feature/story?id=28261213\u0026_slug_=dabo-swinney-ed-orgeron-highest-paid-state-employees\u0026redirected=true\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehighest-paid public employee\u003c/a\u003e in 40 states in 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor its part, the NCAA claims that compensating student athletes would undermine the “amateur” flavor of college sports, damaging fans' enjoyment of the product.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut that argument is increasingly sounding tone-deaf\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd lawmakers are chipping away at the NCAA's stranglehold. At least seven states have passed bills allowing college athletes to make money from their names, images, and likenesses that go into effect next week. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethis trickle of bad news for the NCAA could turn into a flood. If more justices adopt Kavanaugh's aggressive stance, “It could only be a matter of time before all of the NCAA's restrictions on compensation are struck down as antitrust violations,” Tulane sports law administrator Gabe Feldman \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/21/us/supreme-court-ncaa-student-athletes.html?action=click\u0026module=Spotlight\u0026pgtype=Homepage\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold the NYT\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLike Jon Snow, WeWork's making the most of its second chance. From April to May, the company \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/wework-posts-best-sales-since-100000564.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esold more desks\u003c/a\u003e than it had cancellations, making it WeWork's best stretch for sales since September 2019, Bloomberg reported.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAlthough its occupancy rate has improved to 53%, that's still well below its former peak of ~70%.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eGive WeWork some credit\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter shelving its IPO plans in 2019, it went from most-anticipated stock to laughing stock. But then WeWork implemented tough-but-necessary changes under the supervision of major investor SoftBank. It parted ways with CEO Adam Neumann and dramatically cut expenses, including through thousands of layoffs.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile the pandemic was initially a gut punch, it also offered the company \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/wework-imploded-2019-pandemic-brought-it-back-life-n1267957?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ea shot at reinvention\u003c/a\u003e.\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eMore offices are looking for hybrid or remote-friendly setups, and WeWork is once again poised to scratch the labor market's newest itch. The company is already offering more flexible memberships with on-demand booking and access to multiple locations.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eWeWork is tracking for $1.9 billion in revenue and aims to go public this year exactly how you'd expect: a $9 billion SPAC deal with BowX Acquisition Corp.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSteven Spielberg's production company, Amblin Partners, is speeding toward the future of entertainment with a \u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2021/film/news/steven-spielberg-netflix-amblin-deal-1235001513/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew Netflix deal\u003c/a\u003e. The company has agreed to produce two or more movies a year for the streamer, some of which could be directed by Spielberg himself.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe deal won't affect Amblin's current partnership with Universal, to which it supplies three-to-five movies a year.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis is a sign of \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/netflix-strikes-deal-with-filmmaker-steven-spielberg-11624293296?mod=e2tw\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echanging times\u003c/a\u003e for Hollywood: In a 2018 interview, Spielberg said this about streaming: “You certainly, if it's a good show, deserve an Emmy, but not an Oscar.” This year, Netflix received 36 Oscar nominations.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAnd Netflix wants more\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe company plans to release 70 movies in 2021—which may seem overly ambitious, but streaming companies are in a sprint to stockpile the most, and best, content. Just last month, Amazon acquired MGM, and with it the historic studio's entire back catalog, including all the \u003cem\u003eJames Bond\u003c/em\u003e,\u003cem\u003e Legally Blonde\u003c/em\u003e, and \u003cem\u003eRocky\u003c/em\u003e movies.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eStriking a deal with Spielberg is a flex for Netflix; he has more Oscars under his belt than any other living filmmaker.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp Alas, Wingstop's embrace of the mighty thigh has not come about because consumers finally realized they've been overpaying for the worst cut of chicken.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt's because wings are in short supply. \u003c/strong\u003eThey've been a popular takeout dish during the pandemic, but now that strong demand is crashing up against a nationwide chicken shortage, prices are flying. Wingstop's wholesale prices \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/21/business/chicken-thighs-wingstop/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehave risen\u003c/a\u003e from as little as 98 cents last year to over $3 now, according to the company's CEO.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThighstop won't just be a departure from Wingstop's namesake business. The company will use its existing physical restaurants to prepare the meals, but the menu will be available online only as Wingstop tries to keep its \"digital momentum\" from the pandemic going. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDigital sales now account for 65% of Wingstop's business and topped $1 billion last year. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eChanging demographics have boosted dark meat's popularity in recent years.
